Singapore: International Society of the Learning Sciences, pp. 35-43. info:doi/10.22318/icls2016.26 Persistence is necessary for learning, yet students have difficulty persisting at academic tasks, especially when faced with challenge. One context where students seem to persist is gameplay. This paper investigates whether an educational computer programming game can enhance student persistence and learning. Students were assigned to play either the Full version of a game, or a Minimal version of the game that ablated several common game features. Contrary to our hypotheses, we found that students who played the Full Game persisted less at challenging tasks, wrote less challenging code during gameplay, and were less willing to learn more about coding in the future. Ultimately, players of the Full Game also learned less than students who played the Minimal Game.
